content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "REVERSE" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's not too hard in Reverse, interesting in Shortest and fun in Fastest.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle. It's fun for shortest and not impossible for reverse either. Difficulty is just right for CoC.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun and easier than it may seem. Since any repeat in numbers starts a cycle, it's not too complex.

I can honestly say it took longer to code it so that there wouldn't be an extra space at the end to pass the tests than to code the actual solution. I ***HATE*** that!

But I do like the problem, it was fun to code. Finish this up so I can approve it :)

Validators and Tests need to come in pairs that test the same thing. Right now if somebody handles the "end at 1" cycles incorrectly, they pass all Tests but then fail half the Validators.
You could have a set where the given N repeats, a set where some later value is the first to repeat, a set that ends on 1, and a set with a very long sequence.

Yes this is a CoC but this is not a hard problem if you know how to make a function:))
or something how ever i think if u make it a reverse instead of fastest which is too easy or shortest which is a bit trickyer cause in many languages i think there are tricks or functions which return ur answer but in reverse i think it would be very good so pls make it reverse or i am sorry for ur downvote, normally i could just make it reverse but i want u to read this message, you do good work se keep doing ;)
I don't think the second line of output is really necessary. The information on the second line is actually already in the first.

Thanks for your message.

Yes, it's not a difficult challenge, but I can make it available for the reverse one too. In that way, we can have this challenge with two difficulties:
- the easiest one (not in reverse) : can learn some basics to beginners with a simple challenge
- the harder one (the reverse mode): where the hardest part will be to find how the sequence works and when to stop.

I will activate the reverse mode

I added the case where the sequence begin by 1, but in reality, due to the nature of the challenge, it's handled the same way than the other tests.
For the very long sequence, I made a program which try to find the largest sequence. This program tried all the sequences from 1 to 100 000 000, and the largest it found has a length of 20 (one of these is already in the tests). I don't think I will be able to find a larger sequence.

two examples:
15999 -> [15999, 269, 121, 6, 36, 45, 41, 17, 50, 25, 29, 85, 89, 145, 4
2, 20, 4, 16, 37, 58]
60007799 -> [60007799, 296, 121, 6, 36, 45, 41, 17, 50, 25, 29, 85, 89, 145
, 42, 20, 4, 16, 37, 58]

Thanks for your comment :)

Yes, the last space .... I know that some people struggles with this. What language are you using ? 
For example, I made it in python, and using the join function, there is no problem to handle that ;)

I modified a little bit the tests to be more related to the validators and now my submission is complete.
C++. There's no join function. I don't know what causes this since some problems allow extra spaces and new lines at the end, and some don't.

All depends on the way the output is formatted. In some Clash of Code, people add vonlontarily a space at the end. However, I thinks it's better to not add a space at the end (this space is useless in the final output and it can be confusing to end an output by an invisible char I think).

For your problem, before printing the output, why not just removing the last char of your response (which is the last space) ? Normally, it can be done easily in every language (I'm not a C++ developper, but if I'm not wrong the pop_back() function should work)

You then have to create a string where you shove everything into it instead of outputting directly. If you've coded the program to end abruptly, then it doesn't really work. Different parts of the code will output different things, so if you've coded it one way and then try to shove everything into a string instead, you may very well have to change a lot of the logic around.
I improved a little the tests to be more related to the validators
